awd_titl_txt: Social Psychological Intervention to Increase Gender Diversity in Tech Companies
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  

The principal investigator will conduct a postdoctoral research fellowship at the University of Washington Seattle that includes conducting a research project and implementing a professional development plan. The research focuses on micro inclusions in the workplace - that is, respectful treatment from others that include women and their contributions to shared work goals, and whether such micro inclusions can increase women’s sense of fit and improve outcomes in the STEM companies where they work. This research offers a novel framework of what inclusion can be at work. Inclusion is not only being well represented or having inclusive policies. It also means being able to contribute skills and expertise and being treated in ways that allow those contributions. The study will provide the foundation for a new class of interventions and strategies that focus on small everyday behaviors to improve employee and company outcomes. In doing so, the project holds promise to shed light on how companies can become more attractive to a wider and more diverse population of applicants interested in joining and staying in the STEM workforce.

The research project has three aims. The first aim is to test whether micro inclusions improve organizational outcomes for women, including those of color, in STEM companies, and show that this is mediated by sense of fit. In a correlation survey design, the investigator will assess how often employees from real-world companies experience micro inclusions from their managers and test whether such experiences are correlated with employee job satisfaction, motivation, company trust, and turnover intentions. The second aim is to distinguish micro inclusions from other positive treatments. In online experimental designs, the investigator will manipulate whether participants receive a micro inclusion or other forms of positive treatments (e.g., being invited to a team happy hour) and assess their sense of fit and organizational outcomes. The third aim assesses whether a randomized control trial video intervention can increase managers’ use of micro inclusions with their team. This work will demonstrate a novel interpersonal strategy (i.e., micro inclusions) that companies can immediately begin to use to supplement their diversity and inclusion efforts. Additionally, this work may offer insights on how to begin to create company culture change. If micro inclusions are shown to improve company outcomes, and the intervention successfully changes managers’ behaviors, future interventions might establish, convey, and reinforce norms of micro inclusions to increase gender diversity at work. 

The project responds to the STEM Education Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (STEM Ed PRF) program that aims to enhance the research knowledge, skills, and practices of recent doctorates in STEM, STEM education, education, and related disciplines to advance their preparation to engage in fundamental and applied research that advances knowledge within the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Organizations sometimes attempt to improve inclusion by focusing their efforts on static organizational qualities, such as numerical representation, that signal to people that they could belong and fit. Yet, an understudied critical aspect of inclusion at work is also whether people are allowed to contribute to shared goals. This research highlights the importance of directly soliciting, supporting, and valuing people’s contributions on their sense of fit and company commitment through positive interpersonal treatment called, microinclusions. We have produced two publications in high impact journals (e.g., Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, Psychological Science in the Public Interest) addressing the three main program objectives: to establish the theory of microinclusions; to specify and establish microinclusive treatment from other forms of positive treatment; to examine the cultural aspects of a company that help increase positive experiences in academic departments.

 

In this research, we show that both men and women’s sense of fit in technology organizations increased when receiving microinclusive treatment that valued and recognized their contributions at work. This gain, however, was greater for women because it remedied women’s concerns that they will be treated in biased ways. Later experiments also revealed that microinclusions increased women’s sense of fit and their commitment to keep working in technology companies more than socially “nice” treatment such as team events and happy hours. This research shows that a critical factor in belonging and company retention for women in technology organizations is about whether their contributions will be valued, recognized, and celebrated at work.

 

One goal of the grant is to disseminate the research, especially to those who can help change technology companies, or Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math domains more broadly. We continue to reach a wide and varied audience with multiple dissemination efforts, including talks, conference presentations, and through the PI’s website and LinkedIn. We have disseminated our work through the University of Washington Newswebsite, the Society of Personality and Social Psychology Character and Context Blog, and Harvard Business Review. The PI has had several speaking engagements at a variety of institutions (University of Washington, Stanford University, University of California – Los Angeles), professional conferences (Society for Personality and Social Psychology; Society of the Psychological Study of Social Issues; Society of Experimental Social Psychology), and companies (NSF, MaineHealth Institute for Research).
